body.p:
To his Excellency
Beriah Magoffin
Governor of the Commonwealth of Ky

we the undersigned members of the bar of Greenupsburg Ky -- and citizens of the County of Greenup, would respectfully represent, that William R. Smith of Greenup County, was Indicted -- by the Grand Jury of Greenup County ^for keeping a tipling house^ on on the day of May 1861 -- and the Defendent came into Court -- & confessed a judgement -- but with a promise of the Commonwealth's Atty R. H. Stanton that he would have the fine remited, by the Governor Except -- cost if possible -- the offense consisted of the Defendent having sold a qut of Liqour an on Election Day -- and probably a Drink or such a matter besides the quart -- Smith is a man in humble circumstances, with a large family to Support, and owing to the presssure of the times & scarcity of money -- a sale of his property would result in a great Sacrifice, to the Defendent Smith In view of all these facts -- we
would respectfully represent, that the circumstances by which this case is Surrounded, Should claim Executive clemency & interposition --
we therefore petition your Excellency -- to remit the fine Except cost

Geo. E. Roe Attorny for Greenup co
James Morton Late J G C
Charles M Smith
Robert A Smith
Edward G Warnock
H C Davidson
J. C. Kouns
John E. Winn
M. S. Kouns
D. A. Hinton
Jno, C, Adams Presiding
Judge for Greenup County
John Tanner Jr.
Allen myers Jailor
W C Ireland
J. L. Dupuy
Ed. J Dulkin
L. D. Ross
Jesse Coner
Hugh craycraft
A. L. Reid
Jefferson Keaton
I concur in the above recommendation

Greenup Cir. Ct
$60 } Tipling
Wm R. Smith
Issd Apr 24. 1862
